A combination of the President’s style + a predetermined goal to remove him from office, set this impeachment in motion the day after the election. I'll support a process that leads to more transparency, without the influence of politics, but today’s vote does the opposite. (3/3)

The resolution:
-Further restricts which Members are allowed in SCIF
-Allows Majority Chairmen to veto subpoenaing Republican witnesses + questions asked
-Gives Chairman Nadler authority to dismiss the President’s legal counsel
-undermines/politicizes Intel & Judiciary Committees

Should one party have veto power over the other subpoenaing witnesses or over questions that can be asked? Of course not. Should the Chairman of any Committee have the power to deny the President’s legal counsel in the room? Again, of course not. #utpol

The bill:
🐄was negotiated w/input from agricultural stakeholders & labor organizations 
🐄makes meaningful reforms to the H-2A agricultural guestworker program
🐄creates a first-of-its-kind, merit-based visa program specifically designed for the nation’s agricultural sector

Our relationship with Taiwan is an important alliance and we must do all we can to empower their democracy and free-market economy—I am hopeful that we can soon vote on the House floor in support of this crucial legislation. #TAIPEIAct #HFAC (2/2) pic.twitter.com/FottaYIstA

Today the TAIPEI Act was voted unanimously through the committee. The bipartisan bill creates a pathway to legal status for the dedicated farmworkers who have helped provide food for our nation for decades, and it ensures that Utah’s farmers and ranchers will have the year-round workforce they need to be successful.

I am pleased to join a bipartisan group of my colleagues to introduce a pragmatic and realistic proposal to address the immigration reforms that our agriculture sector desperately needs: the "Farm Workforce Modernization Act.” pic.twitter.com/8Ds4ON2ltR

FULL RELEASE: https://curtis.house.gov/press-releases/curtis-supports-u-s-allied-kurds-with-new-proposals/ …

Today I cosponsored and voted for H.J. Res. 77, a bipartisan resolution opposing the decision to end certain United States efforts to prevent Turkish military operations against Syrian Kurdish forces in Northeast Syria.

It passed the House this afternoon 354 to 60🇺🇸

I'm proud to cosponsor this bill. The Kurds have been some of our strongest allies and abandoning them to the will of Turkey sends a devastating signal to partners around the world and is harmful not only to the Kurds but to American interests in the region. #HFAC #utpol https://twitter.com/RepLizCheney/status/1184513950664278016 …

While we have seen efforts from the Chinese Communist Party to suggest these organic uprisings are a result of outside forces, leaders of the House and Senate are eager to lend support to Hong Kong’s freedom fighters. We #StandWithHongKong. 🇭🇰🇺🇸

This afternoon the bipartisan #HongKongHumanRightsandDemocracyAct passed the House. This important bill focuses on punishing human rights abuses, pushing back on China’s grip on Hong Kong, and creating a system that ensures Hong Kong retains its autonomy. #utpol https://twitter.com/RepJohnCurtis/status/1177584059507269632 …

I called a meeting with county and city elected officials in Blanding, Utah with guest @NNPrezNez Navajo Nation President Jonathan Nez which resulted in plans to work together for the benefit of all San Juan County residents. #utpol pic.twitter.com/Ea3khBNdXm

In addition to the recreational aspects of the county, I also toured an uranium mill and met with employees to discuss the ways the mill contributes to the rural economy. #utpol pic.twitter.com/lQlqUPG8ZG

I spent time on the San Juan River rafting & stopping to study ruins and other historically and spiritually significant landmarks. Accompanied by local guides, we discussed recreation permitting, the SOAR Act, and how legislation affects their lives & livelihoods. pic.twitter.com/rxcPtb6dsp

I joined a group of representatives from the Hopi tribe, including Honorable Vice Chairman Clark W. Tenakhongva, Friends of Cedar Mesa (FOCM), and Woods Canyon Archeological Consultants to learn more about the tribe’s ties to the land. pic.twitter.com/00zRnHuNT7

My time in San Juan County exploring public lands was invaluable, and only proved what I already knew. We all love our public lands, want what is best for them, and if we come together and actually listen to each other, progress will come. #utpol pic.twitter.com/cayXB7PhZl
